title: 'Pride' Review: Sweeping History Made Personal
summary: The six-part documentary tells the story of LGBTQ+ civil rights in America through intimate stories. Assumptions will be made in advance about "Pride," the ambitious six-part documentary about the history of LGBTQ+ civil rights in America. And some will be correct. Is it celebratory? Yes. Is it self-congratulatory? To a degree. Is it a sweeping, encyclopedic, overly ambitious, Ken Burns-ian attempt to be the last word on the subject? On the contrary.

title: 'The Upshaws' Review: Family Clatters
summary: The new comedy from Regina Y. Hicks and Wanda Sykes feels dated, clumsy and oh-so-not funny. To say that "The Upshaws" is stuck in the '70s doesn't quite do it. The 1970s? Or the 1870s? Created by writer Regina Y. Hicks and the comedian Wanda Sykes, the show boasts production values that might easily have cost more than, say, $14.75. The laugh track is like your neighbor's broken car alarm. The aesthetics evoke the era of "Good Times" or "All in the Family," although the social messaging is absent-in fact, the jokes are entrenched in racial stereotyping and clichés. "The Upshaws" was meant to be transgressive, one imagines. It's harder to imagine who'll be laughing.

Drinking straws made with PHA are already in use, and other single-use products are far along in development with major customer brands. Unlike traditional plastics sourced from nonrenewable fossil fuels, PHA is sourced from renewable natural ingredients.

title: Vaccination Debate Isn't New, Interests Still Conflict
summary: To the sensible cost-benefit analysis of Charles L. Hooper and David R. Henderson, it can be added that such considerations were discussed in the 1760s, during the Enlightenment smallpox-inoculation debate.. To the sensible cost-benefit analysis of Charles L. Hooper and David R. Henderson ("Youth Pay a High Price for Covid Protection," op-ed, May 4), it can be added that such considerations were discussed in the 1760s, during the Enlightenment smallpox-inoculation debate. Swiss mathematician Daniel Bernoulli and French scientist and man of letters Jean le Rond d'Alembert calculated and argued about the comparative life-expectancy risk and reward of being inoculated versus doing without. Both regretted the absence of age-specific mortality data for smallpox victims. Bernoulli thought existing statistics compelling enough to urge inoculation for all; d'Alembert advised waiting until fuller data became available. Today, for a different health crisis, we have such data and vastly better means of immunization, which, if used intelligently, make policy-formation easier.

title: Biden's Not-So-Clean Energy Transition
summary: The International Energy Agency exposes the hidden environmental costs and infeasibility of going green.. The International Energy Agency, the world's pre-eminent source of energy information for governments, has entered the political debate over whether the U.S. should spend trillions of dollars to accelerate the energy transition favored by the Biden administration. You know, the plan to use far more "clean energy" and far less hydrocarbons-the oil, natural gas and coal that today supply 84% of global energy needs. The IEA's 287-page report released this month, "The Role of Critical Minerals in Clean Energy Transitions," is devastating to those ambitions. A better title would have been: "Clean Energy Transitions: Not Soon, Not Easy and Not Clean."

title: My Life-Changing Trip to Europe as a Food-Obsessed Teenager
summary: Food writer Alexander Lobrano first visited Europe in the 1970s on a summer vacation with his mother. She wanted him to learn about the Roman Empire. He wanted to eat.. THE SUMMER of 1972, my mother gave me the world. After receiving her inheritance from my Bostonian grandmother, she announced that we'd spend July and August in Europe. Leaving my father and sister, the baby of the family, behind in Westport, Conn., she would take me, then 14, and my two younger brothers to the Continent for the first month. Then we'd meet Dad and my sister in Paris and spend three weeks together touring France and the United Kingdom.

summary: Borrowers are selling debt at low rates and with easier terms, especially in Europe. Risky companies are selling junk bonds at a record pace, getting ultralow borrowing costs and increasingly loose borrowing terms, such as "pick-your-poison" clauses.

title: Cathay Sells Dollar Bonds as Investors See Aviation's Prospects Improving
summary: Yield on carrier's $650 million bond points to robust demand. Cathay Pacific Airways Ltd. sold its first dollar bonds in more than two decades, seizing on debt investors' willingness to fund pandemic-ravaged airlines as the industry's prospects improve.

title: Surge in China's Factory-Gate Prices Adds to Inflation Worries
summary: Factory-gate prices rose 6.8% in April, the fastest growth since October 2017. HONG KONG-China's factory-gate prices jumped by the most in 3½ years in April, driven by surging commodities prices, raising concerns that inflationary pressures could spread globally.

title: Renewable Power Capacity Jumped in 2020
summary: Addition to renewables capacity was 45% greater than prior year's gain, marking biggest jump since 1999. Renewable power capacity grew at its fastest pace this century in 2020, the International Energy Agency said Tuesday, raising its growth forecast for wind and solar power for this year and next.

title: China's Census Highlights Its Looming Population Problem
summary: After weeks of delay, China issued census data showing a minuscule rise in its population in 2020. China said its population hit 1.41 billion in 2020, eking out a tiny rise from the previous year, underlining how the world's most populous nation is going to have to face its demographic challenges sooner than expected.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Glenn Youngkin Wins GOP Nomination for Virginia Governor
summary: Former Carlyle Group boss beat a crowded GOP field, pointing to his business record and support for Trump policies. Virginia Republican leaders nominated political newcomer Glenn Youngkin for governor, betting on the former private-equity executive, who embraced elements of former President Donald Trump's policy agenda, to turn around the party's fortunes in a state that has moved sharply toward the Democrats.

title: NBC Says It Won't Air the Golden Globes in 2022
summary: The network's decision comes as Amazon, Netflix and WarnerMedia say they will boycott the awards ceremony over ethical violations and lack of diversity at the organization that runs it. NBC said it will not broadcast the Golden Globes next year after several major entertainment companies and stars indicated that they would not participate in the awards show or work with the Hollywood Foreign Press Association, the organization that oversees the event.

title: First Covid-19 Vaccine Cleared for U.S. Adolescents
summary: First shot approved in U.S. for children paves way for inoculations before summer camps, start of next school year. U.S. health regulators have for the first time cleared a Covid-19 vaccine's use in children, paving the way for many to be immunized before summer camps and the start of the next school year.

title: Unions Say Mexican Auto-Parts Maker Is Violating Trade Deal
summary: Complaint is first test of USMCA's labor-dispute provision. WASHINGTON-U.S. and Mexican labor groups filed a complaint against a Mexican auto-parts manufacturer, alleging that it violated the U.S.-Mexico-Canada Agreement by suppressing its workers' rights to unionize.
